event.text: Victory in Europe Day (VE-Day) is declared, ending the European portion of the Second World War

Her Majesty's Canadian ships Annapolis, Columbia, Niagara, St. Clair, St. Croix and St. Francis, ex-American destroyers from the fifty given to Great Britain in exchange for bases, are commissioned into the Royal Canadian Navy
The British Commonwealth Air Training Plan begins operations when students began training at No. 1 Service Flying Training School at Camp Borden, Ontario
a Wellington bomber of No.407 Squadron, Royal Canadian Air Force, sinks the German submarine U-283 in the North Atlantic

the 1st and 2nd Canadian Divisions are authorized as the Canadian Active Service Force. The Royal Canadian Navy, Royal Canadian Navy Reserve and Royal Canadian Navy Volunteer Reserve are placed on active service

Pilot Officer S.R. Henderson, a Canadian serving in No.206 Squadron, Royal Air Force, becomes the first Canadian to participate in an operational sortie during the Second World War when he serves as the lead navigator in a bomber force attacking German warships
Canada declares war on Germany
convoy HX-1 sails from Halifax for Great Britain with a local escort including HMCS St. Laurent and HMCS Saguenay
the Honourable Norman McLeod Rogers is appointed Minister of National Defence

S/L W.I. Clements, attached to No.53 (Blenheim) Squadron, Royal Air Force, becomes the first member of the Royal Canadian Air Force to fly over enemy territory when his squadron makes a long distance reconnaissance flight over Germany
the formation of the Organization and Training Division at RCAF headquarters is authorized
the first Canadian troop convoy sails for Britain escorted out of Halifax by HMC ships Ottawa, Restigouche, Fraser and St. Laurent
the first group of the 1st Canadian Infantry Division arrives in the United Kingdom

the governments of the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia and New Zealand sign an agreement to establish the British Commonwealth Air Training Plan under the supervision of the Royal Canadian Air Force
the second section of the 1st Canadian Infantry Division arrives in the United Kingdom

the awarding of Distinguished Flying Cross (each) to two Canadians serving in the Royal Air Force, Pilot-Officer S.R. Henderson and Wing-Commander J.F. Griffiths, is announced. They are the first Canadians to be decorated during the Second World War
the third Canadian Contingent arrives in Great Britain
No.110 (Army Co-Operation) Squadron sails from Halifax for Britain where it arrives on 25 February, the first Canadian air force squadron to reach Great Britain
No. 1 Initial Training School is opened in Toronto to provide the first training for British Commonwealth Air Training Plan students
No. 1 Air Navigation School was formed at Trenton, Ontario, to provide navigation training for British Commonwealth Air Training Plan students

the first members of No. 112 (Army Co-Operation) Squadron, based in Winnipeg, sail from Canada for Liverpool where they arrive eight days later as the second Royal Canadian Air Force squadron overseas
the Honourable Charles G. Power is appointed Minister of National Defence for Air
HMS ships St. Laurent, Restigouche and Skeena sail from Halifax for Britain to join the Allied naval defence forces
No. 1 Air Observer School is opened in Malton, Ontario, to train British Commonwealth Air Training Plan students in air observation duties

Canadian warships come under fire for the first time when HMCS St. Laurent and HMCS Restigouche encounter German warships at St. Valery en Caux,nac,Harold Harden,1325,No HMCS Restigouche or St. Laurent - general about germans in atlantic
No. 1 (Fighter) Squadron sails from Halifax for Great Britain
the Canadian government declares war on Italy
HMCS St. Laurent and HMCS Restigouche evacuate military personnel from Le Havre, France, exchanging gunfire with German artillery batteries in the process
The Honourable Charles Gavan Power is appointed Minister of Department of National Defence
Canadian troops board transport vessels in St. Malo and Brest to leave France for England after the aborted attempt to support the British and French armies
HMCS Fraser evacuates Free French troops and future Canadian Governor-General, Lieutenant-Colonel G.P. Vanier, from France
the last class of Royal Canadian Navy Volunteer Reserve officers graduate from HMCS Stone Frigate
HMCS Fraser is lost after colliding with a British warship, HMS Calcutta in the Bay of Biscay
861 German and Italian prisoners of war are rescued by HMCS St. Laurent after their transport ship was torpedoed on its way to Canada
the Honourable James Layton Ralston is appointed Minister of National Defence
Les Fusiliers Mont-Royal and The Cameron Highlanders of Ottawa arrive in Iceland to complete the Canadian >Z= Force stationed there
HMCS Skeena rescues the crew of a torpedoed merchant ship, the SS Manipor, in the waters north of Scotland
HMCS Prince Robert, after conversion from a merchant vessel, is commissioned as an armed merchant cruiser
the Canadian Armoured Corps is authorized
"HMS Windflower, the first corvette built in Canada, is commissioned into the Royal Navy with a Canadian crew. She is turned over to the Royal Canadian Navy in 1941
HMCS Margaree is lost in a collision with SS Port Fairy in the North Atlantic
HMCS Bras D'Or founders in the North Atlantic
AZ@ Force, with the exception of The Cameron Highlanders of Ottawa, sails from Iceland for Great Britain
HMCS Collingwood, the first corvette built in Canada for the RCN, is commissioned
the first draft of British Commonwealth Air Training Plan graduates arrive in England for service
HMCS Prince Henry is commissioned as an Armed Merchant Cruiser
HMCS Royal Roads is commissioned as a training establishment for Probationary Sub-Lieutenants
1st Canadian Corps is formed in the United Kingdom under the command of Lieutenant-General A.G.L. McNaughton
HMCS Prince David is commissioned as an Armed Merchant Cruiser
a Commonwealth agreement of 17 December 1939 provides for the future establishment of purely Canadian air force units for newly-trained Canadians to join in Europe
the 5th Canadian Motorcycle Regiment, CASF, (BCD) is converted and redesignated The British Columbia Dragoons

the Rush-Bagot Agreement of 1817, which restricted the number of naval vessels allowed on the Great Lakes, is modified to allow both American and Canadian naval vessels to operate on the Great Lakes in greater numbers
HMCS Otter burns and sinks in the approaches to Halifax
seven Royal Canadian Navy corvettes arrive in St. John's, Newfoundland, to begin operations as the Newfoundland Escort Force
Newfoundland's sea defences are brought under Canadian control with the appointment of Commodore L.W. Murray, RCN, as the commander of Newfoundland Force
warships of the Newfoundland Escort Force begin convoy escort operations in the North Atlantic Ocean
the Canadian government announces its intention to form a Canadian Women's Army Corps
HMCS Wasaga is commissioned, becoming the first Canadian-built Bangor-class minesweeper
the Canadian Women's Auxiliary Air Force is authorized, later becoming the Royal Canadian Air Force (Women’s Division)
HMC Ships Assiniboine and Restigouche escort HMS Prince of Wales, with Prime Minister Winston Churchill aboard, into Placentia Bay, Newfoundland
the Canadian Women’s Army Corps is authorized
HMCS Chambly and HMCS Moose Jaw sink the German submarine U-501 off the coast of Greenland. This is the first U-boat kill made by the Royal Canadian Navy
HMCS Levis (a corvette) is torpedoed and sunk in the North Atlantic
the University Air Training Squadrons are formed
AC@ Force (Canadian troops under the command of Brigadier J.K. Lawson) sails from Vancouver for Hong Kong
the RCAF is awarded its first George Cross when LAC K.M. Gravell is posthumously awarded the decoration for the attempt to rescue his pilot from their crashed Tiger Moth aircraft
the 1st Armoured Car Regiment (Royal Canadian Dragoons) sails from Canada for Britain as part of the 5th Canadian Armoured Division
HMCS Halifax is commissioned into the RCN
Canada declares war on Romania, Hungary, Finland and Japan"
HMCS Windflower is lost after a collision with SS Zypenburg on the Grand Banks of Newfoundland
the United States, Great Britain and other nations declare war on Japan
gallantry shown by Company Sergeant-Major J.R. Osborn, Royal Winnipeg Grenadiers, in action against the Japanese at Hong Kong on this date led to the posthumous award of the Victoria Cross
Hong Kong surrenders to the Japanese forces
the Canadian Naval Board is established
the Canadian Women's Auxiliary Air Force is renamed the Royal Canadian Air Force (Women's Division)
HMCS Spikenard is torpedoed and sunk in the North Atlantic
nine Canadian squadrons (four bomber, four fighter and one coastal) take part in the chase of three German warships in the AChannel Dash@
the Canadian Women's Army Corps is granted full Army status as ""a Corps of the Active Militia of Canada
the first Canadian 'Cruiser' tanks arrive in England
No.413 Squadron begins its transfer from the Shetland Isles to Ceylon to strengthen Allied air defences in the Pacific
Air Vice-Marshal E.W. Stedman is appointed the first Director General of Air Research for the Royal Canadian Air Force

Squadron Leader L.J. Birchall and his crew, flying a PBY-5 flying boat, spot a Japanese naval force heading for the island of Ceylon. Their warning allowed the island's defenders to prepare for the Japanese attempt to take the island, an attack which fails. Birchall is later known as "The Saviour of Ceylon
at least fifteen Canadian members of the Royal Canadian Air Force and the Royal Air Force help the Ceylonese defend the island against the Japanese attempt to conquer it
the First Canadian Army formed in the United Kingdom under the command of Lieutenant-General A.G.L. McNaughton
No. 417 (Spitfire) Squadron, Royal Canadian Air Force, is transferred from Great Britain to Egypt to support the Allied operations in the Middle East
